metadata.case_name: Vajrapani Naidu & Anr. v. New Theatre Carnatic Talkies Ltd., Coimbatore

facts.text: Appellants (lessors: Vajrapani Naidu and Bangarammal) granted lease of open site in Coimbatore to Abirama Chettiar under registered deed dated September 19, 1934, for 20 years at annual rental of Rs. 1,080/- for putting up building suitable for theatre.
Abirama Chettiar constructed theatre on site and assigned rights to New Theatre Carnatic Talkies Ltd. (Company/respondent). Company attorned to lessors and recognised as tenant under 1934 lease.

Lease terms: land for constructing buildings for cinema/drama; option for renewal 20 years on fresh terms; on expiry/termination, lessee to pay arrears, dismantle constructions, demolish walls, deliver vacant possession; lessors right to re-enter via court after dismantling if not done.
Lessors served notice on Company on March 9, 1954, to vacate and surrender vacant possession.
Company failed to comply; lessors filed suit for ejectment and mesne profits at Rs. 1,000/- per month from September 19, 1954.
Subordinate Judge, Coimbatore, awarded decree for possession and mesne profits at Rs. 350/- per month and costs.
Company appealed to District Court, Coimbatore, transferred to Madras High Court.
During pendency of appeal, G.O. No. 608 dated February 10, 1958, extended Madras City Tenants Protection Act 3 of 1922 (as amended by Act 19 of 1955) to Coimbatore municipal town.
Company applied under s.9 for order directing lessors to convey site for price fixed by court.
Panchapakesa Iyer J. directed lessors to sell site under s.9 at full market value on date of order; trial court to appoint Commissioner for value as on July 28, 1958.
Appeal under cl.15 Letters Patent against single judge order dismissed.
High Court granted certificate; lessors appealed to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Company is entitled under s.9 of the Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1922, notwithstanding the terms of the lease, to an order calling upon the lessors to sell the land demised under the deed dated September 19, 1934.
Whether the terms of s.9 of the Act infringe the fundamental right under Arts. 19(1)(f) and 31(1) of the Constitution, of the lessors, and s.9 is on that account invalid.

petitioner_arguments.text: Stipulation in registered lease deed requiring tenant to deliver vacant possession after dismantling constructions is a 'stipulation as to the erection of buildings' under proviso to s.12, disentitling Company to s.9 benefit.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.12 proviso, Madras City Tenants Protection Act 1922

petitioner_arguments.text: s.9 imposes unreasonable restriction on right to hold/dispose property under Art.19(1)(f); price at lowest market value in 7 years prior (pre-1960 amendment) unreasonable under Art.31(1).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1), Constitution; s.9 as amended by Act VI 1926

respondent_arguments.text: Stipulation relates to vacation/delivery of possession, not 'as to the erection of buildings'; proviso to s.12 narrow, covers only size/nature/materials/purpose of erection.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.12, Madras City Tenants Protection Act 1922

respondent_arguments.text: Company offered to pay market value as on date of single judge order.

court_reasoning.text: s.12 first part protects tenant rights (incl. s.3 compensation, s.9 purchase) from contract; proviso exception strict, only for stipulations 'as to the erection of buildings' (e.g. size/nature/materials/purpose), not removal/demolition on expiry.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Stipulation to remove buildings not 'as to erection'; exception narrowly construed per Act's object to protect tenants hoping no eviction if fair rent paid.

court_reasoning.text: s.9 not unreasonable under Art.19(1)(f): limited to pre-extension leases for building construction; effectuates mutual understanding, prevents unearned increment exploitation, conserves materials; in public interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Does not deprive property but gives effect to real agreement inducing tenant construction.

court_reasoning.text: No need decide pre-1960 compensation (lowest 7yr value) reasonableness as Company offers current market value; severable if invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 1960 amendment changes (min area, avg 3yr value); academic here.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent (Ayyangar J.): Proviso saves stipulations in registered deeds bearing on/relating to erection (incl. no-build, removal implying no compensation); covers s.3/s.9 rights; lease stipulation qualifies as tenant adverted to erection contingency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reconciles with preamble; tenant not 'hoping no eviction' if stipulated removal.

holdings.text: Company entitled to s.9 order; lease stipulation not within s.12 proviso.

statutes_cited.name: Madras City Tenants Protection Act 3 of 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Core statute: tenant compensation on ejectment (s.3/4); option to purchase land (s.9); contracts not limit rights except registered stipulations re post-contract buildings erection (s.12). Extended to Coimbatore 1958.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Act 19 of 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Amends 1922 Act to allow extension by notification to other towns for pre-extension tenancies.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Act VI of 1926
statutes_cited.relevance: Amends s.9 price to lowest market value in 7 years prior to order.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Act 13 of 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Further amends: sale only min area; price avg market value 3 years prior.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Right to property; challenged as unreasonable restriction/deprivation.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Strict provisions prompted 1922 Act to protect tenants.

outcome.summary: Majority (Shah J. for Gajendragadkar CJ, Shah, Sikri JJ) dismisses appeal, upholds single judge order under s.9 directing sale at market value. Dissent (Ayyangar J. for Wanchoo, Ayyangar JJ) would allow appeal on s.12 interpretation. No order as to costs.
outcome.relief_granted: Company entitled to purchase site at market value fixed per court order.

key_quotes.text: "A stipulation in a lease which is duly registered that the tenant shall on expiry of the lease remove the building constructed by him and deliver vacant possession, is undoubtedly a stipulation relating to the building, but it is not a stipulation as to the erection of building."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Majority distinguishes removal stipulation from 'erection' under s.12 proviso.

key_quotes.text: "Section 12 has manifestly been enacted to effectuate the object of the Act which is set out in the preamble-viz. to give protection to tenants who ... have constructed buildings on others lands in the hope that they would not be evicted so long as they pay a fair rent for the land."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains narrow construction of proviso per Act's protective purpose.

key_quotes.text: "We understand these words to mean a stipulation which bears on or is in relation to the erection of buildings."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissent's broader interpretation of s.12 proviso.
